Dr. M. L. Raney, librarian of
the University, is again to sail to
Europe this week, as the official
representative of the American
Library Association. Dr. Raney
Spent four months in the spring
of 1918 in France and England
as the representative of the Association to establish library service for the American army and
navy overseas. His plans were
accepted by General Pershing and
Admiral Sims, who provided the
necessary tonnage for the transportation of this material to
Europe. The result is that the
Association has thus far shipped
overseas more than two and a half
million volumes. During the period of demobilization, it is the
American Library Association
that is providing the libraries
used in the army schools abroad.

The G. E. Aldred lecturer of
last week was Mr. H. S. Slocum,
whose theme was, "The Duties of
the Young Engineer in the Construction of a Hydro-Electric
Power Plant." The discourse was
accompanied throughout by the
projection of a fine set of slides
illustrating all the phases of the
work.
Mr. Slocum began his lecture
with an outline of the first steps
of the construction of a plant.
These included financial surveys,
designing of the plant, topographical surveys, and building of
roads, cableways and construction camps. The design of the
construction plant, including rock
.crushers, shops, storage places for
cement and coal, is an exceedingly interesting part of the labor.
Plotting of progress charts is
one of the duties that usually fall
to the young , engineer. These
show the cubic yards excavated,
number of men at work, concrete
completed, and other items of
progress and are of great value,
both in'
keeping the efficiency ,up
and in making a permanent record.
In the actual construction the
force is organized into parties,
each of which has the responsibility for one portion of the work.
In one case, for example, one
party made the excavation, built
the lining of the water-tunnel,
and put up the intake tower. A
second lined in the grades, and
inspected the construction. The
third had the construction of the
power house,—establishing the
center lines erecting the steelwork, installing the hydraulic machinery, and checking the lines of
the journals.
The construction of transmission lines is similar to railroad
work. One party clears the right
of way, another makes the excavations for the footings of the
towers, others put in the concrete,
assemble the towers, put them up,
set them on the footing, put on St
the insulators and string the
wires, respectively.
Inspection forms a large part
of the engineer's work. It must
be done with care and thoroughness, with as much attention to
details as to the more prominent
features.
The speaker closed with some
straightforward advice to young
men about to enter the practical
engineering field. They must

EDUCATION AS LIFE WORK
U.S.Commissioner of Education Claxton
Shows Advantages of Teaching as a
Profession --Thinks Teachers will
be Better Paid in Future.

Iffrrbrririt

Kim To.

TO MAKE MANY INVESTIGATIONS
Williams Memorial Expedition To Take
Interesting Route Through Andes-Will
Return Next Fall After Thorough
Study of Mineral Deposits.

The George Huntington Williams Memorial Expedition will
sail from New York on April 18.
The party will consist of Professor Edward W. Berry, professor of palentology, Professor
Joseph T. Singewald, Jr., professor of economic .geology, and Mr.
Luis Velasco, a graduate student
of the department of geology and
a native of Bolivia. They will
proceed direct to Callao, Peru, via
the Panama Canal. After establishing relations with the geologists of the Peruvian Mining
Bureau, they will cross the western range of the Andes on the
Oroga railroad, which is the highest railroad in the world, climbing to an altitude of 15,865 feet
and continue to its terminus at
Huancayo. Here the party will
re-cross the range on mule-back
to the famous mercury mine at
Huancarelica, and after making
a geologic study of them they will
reach the coast of Pisco.
On the peninsula of Paracas,
near Pisco, the carboniferous
beds will be examined and collections of fossils made. From
Pisco the party will proceed to
Bollendo by steamer, and thence

by rail to Lake Titicaca, the highest body of navigable water in
the world. Though lying nestled
in the Andes at an elevation of
13,000 feet, so large is this intramountain lake that the trip
across requires a night's ride by
steamer. The principal goal of
the expedition will then have been
reached—the Andes of Bolivia.
The two chief objective points in
Bolivia and Corocoro and Potosi,
at both of these localities Professor Singewald made important
scientific discoveries during his
1915 expedition, and it is intended
to carry on further and more detailed work there by the William's
expedition. •
Corocoro is the largest copper
district in Bolivia and shares the
unique distinction with the Lake
Superior district of the United
States of having much of the ore
occur in the form of the native
metal. Potosi was the richest and
most productive of the old Spanish silver districts in South America. The mines have been
worked continuously since their
discovery in 1534, and even today
are important producers of tin
and silver.
The eastern range of the Andes
will be crossed at several places
in order to study the geologic
history of that range and its mineralization.
On completing their work in
Bolivia, the party will again

"The Educational Opportunity"
was the subject on which U. S.
Commissioner of Education Philander P. Claxton talked at the
Life Work Lecture last Tuesday.
Mr. Claxton gave these three
questions for consideration before
deciding on a life work: (1)
What can be accomplished for
others by doing the work? (2)
How much pleasure and enjoyment can be got for oneself?
(3) Can a decent living be made
in the work?
In answer to the question of
what can be done for others, Mr.
Claxton emphasized the tremendous need of education brought on
by the war. The war has democratized the world and illiterate
people cannot function in a democracy. The whole world must
be educated so that the democracies may succeed in giving their
people prosperity. The war has
greatly cut down the man power
of the world. To replace this,
labor-saving machines must be
used and this involves teaching
laborers to run the machines.
The pleasures of the school
teacher are very great. The
teacher feels that he is doing
something worth while for society; he sees his former scholars go out into life and gets great
•satisfaction when he hears of
splendid achievements of some of
them; and, greater still, he has
the joy of living with younger
people and watching them develop.
Although the income of the
school teacher is at present
small, Mr. Claxton believes that
we are at the beginning of a period of increasing incomes for
teachers and predicts that soon
instructors will be paid a salary
which will bear a close correlation to the great benefits they
bestow on mankind.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 15, 1919
The Pride of the Navy.

We are neither poor sports nor
hard losers. We have gracefully
suffered defeats enough to refute
that charge, for "Palnutm qui
meruit ferat" has always been the
Hopkins motto, especially in regard to athletic contests. The
Navy lacrosse game—if it can be
called a game—should not, however, fall under the category of
those which Hopkins has lost because of the clean, superior play
of her opponents. The Academy
has sustained a disgrace which
cannot easily be wiped out.
The first half of the game,
though bitterly contested, was free
from the terrific slugging that
characterized the last few minutes
of play. Though the Navy brand
of lacrosse did not have the sportsmanlike character of that of Lehigh and other Hopkins opponents, still we should have registered no kick had the remainder
of the game been so played. At
the end of the half, the score stood
two all. After much seesawing
of the ball, Hopkins finally netted
another goal. Then a peculiar psychological factor entered in. We
shall pay the big Navy team the
delicate compliment that they are
distinctly unlike the Huns, who,
former prisoners in their camps
tell us, were astoundingly arrogant and brutal when winning,
but cajolingly gentle when they
saw they had lost. Navy, seeing

•

that the enemy was in the lead
and that there were only seven
more minutei to play, was, in the
literal sense, out for blood.
"Eggie" Sutton was knocked
out with a deep cut on the head,
and time was called till it could
be bandaged. When he .returned
to the game, his bandaged head
was noticeably a target for the
Annapolis stickmen. After sustaining repeated blows on this injured member, he finally fell under a particularly vicious swing,
and, with blood flowing freely, was
carried from the field.
Four other Black and Blue
stickwielders — Defandorf, Beall,
Baxley and Silberstein, far from
the largest men on the team, the
latter with wide open cuts on the
head — were in quick succession
laid out on the field. Hoffman,
also, received a nasty gash on the
cheek. Time was repeatedy called,
these men pluckily coming back
for more, and several of the Navy
team were ejected for a few minutes. But why go into the details? It was pronounced by experts the finest exhibition of dirty
playing they had ever seen.
Navy had an overwhelming
share of weight and brawn, which
they figured they could use to advantage. Had it come to a mutual slugging match, they would
have had the edge. As it was onesided slugging, not a Navy man
was knocked out or badly cut
while many of the Black and Blue
will show for many a day that
they were in a dirty game. Many
of the cuts were received by the
Hopkins stickers after they had
gotten the ball away.
The score has no bearing on the
issue; we offer no alibis. Had it
been an overwhelming victory for
the 'Varsity, we would voice the
same complaint against dirty
playing. The Schmeissers and
Reaney Wolfe must have felt
deeply the perversion into such
channels of the game they have
done so much to foster; and, indeed, they had no hesitancy in expressing themselves.
Several midshipmen, after the
game admitted that from the
standpoint of lacrosse, Navy was
outplayed; and another advanced
the unique theory that those Navy
men that had a grudge against the
world in general went out for lacrosse as a means of venting their
spleen. At all events, whatever
the molly& of the Annapolis
twelve, Saturday's exhibition is a
blot upon the athletic fame of the
Naval Academy; and should a
repetition of the affair ever occur
where Hopkins is concerned, athletic relations between the two institutions should promptly be
severed.
As for the 'Varsity, they played
the game of their lives and stood
up with the old Hopkins spirit
under the unnecessary punishment. Boys, we're all mighty
damned proud of you!

Shall We Keep Up Our Stride?

Hopkins may well be proud of
her patriotic achievements; she
cannot afford to fall down on the
present test. We shall not attempt to give the reasons for subscribing to the Victory Loan, for
they have been and will be fully
presented to us all. Suffice it to
say that although the stimulus
of actual hostilities has been taken
away, the Fifth Loan has a purpose perhaps even loftier than
that of its predecessors.
A large portion of the loan is
to be used for the rehabilitation of
wounded Americans. We, nearly
all of whom have not endured the
hardships of the trenches, can
hardly put ourselves in the places
of the returned hero with the
stripe on the right arm, perhaps
blinded or maimed for life. Should
he be left to the charity of a fickle
--With that
public, which will soon lose its
something
hero worship? The loan, if it goes
over the top, will insure him adethat college

former ocupation. Moreover, the

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 15, 1919.
MUSICAL CONCERT APRIL 26th.
Haverford Musical Clubs and Hopkins
Glee Club Will Stage Concert and
Dance in C. E.Building—To Take
Place of McCoy Hall Concert.

The Musical Clubs of Ha verford
College and the Glee Club of
Johns Hopkins will give a joint
concert at Homewood on Saturday evening, April 26. Following
the concert there will be a formal
dance. This concert is to take
the place of the McCoy Hall concert, which is staged annually by
the Johns Hopkins Musical Clubs.
It will be one of the leading social
functions of the University this
season as the McCoy Hall concert
has been in years past.
The Haverford Musical Clubs
have had a remarkable season, and
are at their best just at this time.
They consist of a mandolin and
it glee club, and they feature several other intereStina numbers.
The athletic teams of Hopkins and
Haverford have held contests for a
number of years and this concert
by the combine'
d musical clubs is
just another tie which will draw
the two colleges closer together.
The Johns Hopkins Glee Club
has been under the direction of
Prof. Charles H. Bo(thau for the
last two months, and is in fine
shape for the concert on the 26th
of April. There are about thirty
men on the club at this time.
Tickets to the concert and
dance may be secured from any
members of the (nee Club. The
place is the Civil Engineering
Hall, Homewood, and the time is
8 P. M., April 26.

Tennis Match Dates Announced.

The tennis team has just one
more week in which to fit itself
for the opening game with Navy,
at Annapolis, on April 19.
For the-past three weeks Captain Keyes has been kept busy
trying to pick out the men he shall
semi to play Navy. He finally announced that the team will probably consist of Symington, Duffy,
Keyes, Ward and Kesting.
The practice for the remainder
of this week will be mainly devoted to doubles, for which, up to
the present time, no teams have
been selected.
After this week's practice, the
team should be in first rate condition to carry out the schedule
which Manager Hoffmeister has
announced. It is as follows:
April 19—Navy, at Navy.
April 26—George Washington,
at home.
May 3—Western Maryland, at
Western Maryland.
May 9—Princeton, at home.
May 10—Columbia, at home.
May 16—Swarthmore, at home.
M ay 17—Ha verford, at home.
May 23—University of Pennsylvania, at home.
May 24—Delaware College, at
Newark.

IMPORTANCE OF THE LIBRARY
(By Ernest Cushing Richardson, Ph. D., Librarian of Princeton University.)
Somebody has put up to the
University Librarian the question:
how shall a freshman go to work
to get the best use out of the library during his course. The idea
was that a man enters college
with a vague idea that the library
is for use and that it might be
used to better fit him for life
work, or even to help him to enjoy his college life itself, if he
only knew how to go to work at it.
The possible uses of the library
are as various as the men and
their special interest. The uses
made by research professors and
graduate students for the discovery of new knowledge is one
thing; the use by professors for
students in aid of class room
work is another, and the free use
of the library by a student for
his voluntary activities and private tastes is another, or rather
two more.
Use for assigned reading may
be left out of account. The professors will tell about this, inch
by inch. It is to the matter of
free use by a man on his own
initiative that this question
points, and, useful as a library is
for organized teaching and learning, and fundamental as it is for
graduate or undergraduate directed research, its best use for
the undergraduate, is its voluntary use.
* * *
The habit of merely looking
over the literature or even the
titles of the books and periodical
articles bearing on the questions
involved, is one of the very best
possible ways of stimulating
thought and suggesting points of
view. Especially in these modern
days when every one is after some
new thing and modern points of
view, it is in the periodical articles that he must find it. Merely
to look over the periodical indexes, therefore, under any topic
suggest twenty variations,
may
,
aspects or points of view, and the
habit of so doing is invaluable.
It follows, too, that the very frequent running in to glance over
the periodicals which handle the
topics involved is the greatest
possible contribution to a fresh
intellectual interest in these topics, and this is after all the main
thing all along the line. Whatever will kindle the intellectual
interest helps towards good use—
interest kindled, usefulness follows almost without effort.
*

*

*

lege curriculum and would add to
it a capacity for understanding
and 'taking interest immeasurable
in terms of arithmetic.
No doubt, however, the best use
that a freshman can plan to make
of a library his whole course long
is not to browse over good books
but to seek out all the best books
and read at least a few of the
very best. By this is meant to
look over with a certain amount
of care some of the very best elementary looks on all matters of
science or history, literature, or
religion, which do not come
within the field of his courses,
doing this as a part of his fifteen
minutes a day, or putting in all
his spare time on it—if he finds
matters of special interest—when
he has the spare time. It means
still more, however, the frequent
handling of the books which are
recognized as the very best, that
is to say, the classics of literature, ancient and modern. Of
course, the average freshman has
no use to begin with for these
classics. The use even of the
English classics is an acquired
taste. The taste is one, however,
which grows very fast with widening interest in all aspects of
human life and thought. The reason of the value of the classics
is that they are concentrated
food, all such books are a survival of the fittest ttnd they are
the fittest because they concentrate in themselves the largest
amount of human experience.
What they are is what human
experience from the beginning of
the world has found true. Their
value is proved by the fact of
their survival. For this very reason, however, they are strong
meat for beginners. Many never
grow up to really enjoy even their
Shakespeare, and it may , be
doubted whether they can hope
to without some wide practice in
the more diluted literature of humanity—Tennyson, Kipling, Dickens, Thackeray, Trollope, Archibald Marshall.
The most important way of using the library is, after all, simply
using it. The mere habit of use
develops ways of use. A man
cannot systematically make a
point of being among books without finding ways in which their
use profits him. The more he
handles the tools of using such
as the author and subject catalogues, the indexes to periodicals,
and the reference books in general,
so that he is able at any time,
with the least expenditure of effort, to get what he wants over
the counter or from the books on
open shelves, the greater the value
and interest of use becomes. It
is curious to one who deals with
such things to note how skill
multiplies interest as well as results.—The Daily Princetonian.

SOCIAL SCIENCE CLUB MEETS;
OFFICERS ARE ELECTED.

Embryo Engineers Witness Launching
of Steel Ship.

At the first meeting of the Social Science Club, held last week,
Frank Morley, Jr, was elected
president; M. Guttmacher, secretary - treasurer, and Professor
Lovejoy, club counsellor. The aims
of the club are to help college men
get ready intellectually to face the
problems of social readjustments
which will arise in the years to
come, and to give them a view of
the many sides of the social problem. A well informed speaker will
present some questions at a public
meeting of the club, and the next
week an open discussion by the
members of the club will be held.
The club will not be run like a
debating society, which Dr. Lovejoy characterized as an evidence
of the survival in college of juvenile tendencies and a mild form
of college athletics.
Dr. Lovejoy, in addressing the
club, said that even if the college men of today wished to dodge
the questions of the social problem, they could not; because the
questions will be forced upon them
for solution in the next thirty or
forty years.
The topics for discussion for
the remainder of the year are to
be: (1) The indictment of the
Present Social Order; (2) Trade
Unionism; and (3) Bolshevism:
What Is It and What Is Its
Actual Program With Respect to,
(a) Political Organization, (b)
Organization and Management of
Industry, (c) Economic Distribution?
The principal texts to be used
for reference will be: "Political
Ideals," by B. Russell, an extreme
radical; Prof. J. Hollander's "The
Abolition of Poverty," a book that
holds the middle way between the
extremes of radicalism and conservatism; and "Essays in Social
Justice," by Prof. T. N. Carver,
an apologist of individualism.
Meetings of the club are to be
held weekly on Thursday nights,
at 8 P. M., at the Barn. The
charge for active membership for
the remainder of the year will be
50 cents. Active members will
have the privilege of voting and
will at times be assigned active
parts in the discussion. All University students are welcome at
any meeting and assume no obligation to pay dues by corning and
joining in the discussion.
An executive committee was appointed to consider and arrange
to secure speakers, to send out
notices and the like. This committee is composed of the officers
of the club — W. Bloom, H. E.
Niles, C. T. Leber and P. Hayes.

The members of the upper
classes of the Engineering Department were afforded last Saturday
noon an opportunity of witnessing
the launching of one of the 8,800ton steel ships now being built at
the Baltimore Dry Docks and
Shipbuilding Company.
.The party from Hopkins, under
the command of Mr. Pullen, was
able to get "box seats" along the
edge of a pier so close that everything could be seen but the champagne ceremony and the band.
Promptly at 12 the beam was
sawed and the skids began to slip
down the greased ways. Those
who had attended the Aldred lecture on shipbuilding began to look
for the smoke that would indicate
that the high friction was burning the wood; the others watched
the big wave pushed up by the
stern of the ship. After the ship
left the ways, waiting tugs came
up, took the cables that were
thrown to them, and guided the
ship around into the channel.
Before the launching, the budding engineers were taken around
the plant. The large drydock with
a Norwegian ship on the blocks,
was the first object of interest.
The men were replacing a number
of bent plates, the accident being
caused (according to several wild.
conjectures) by a torpedo, or maybe a typhoon. After this, they were
shown the mold-loft, where the
wooden templates were being
made. The next stop was at the
shop where the plates and ribs
were cut, shaped and punched.
These trips are made by the engineers nearly every week, giving
the students a chance to observe
time practical as well as the theoretical part of their future profession.

The Johns Hopkins baseball
team will leave Baltimore this
Thursday morning for their northern trip, which will include four
games in different northern cities. On Thursday afternoon the
Black and Blue ball tossers will
stack up against the strong
Columbia University nine in New
York. Friday will be a day of
rest for the team, and on Saturday morning they will journey to
New Haven to tackle the Yale
nine.'
The team will return to New
York Sunday morning and will
remain there Sunday and Monday. They will leave the big city
Thesday morning for Swartlunore,
remaining there the night after
the game with Swarthmore.
Wednesday morning the nine will
leave for Haverford, Pa., to play
the Haverford team that afternoon.
This is the first time that the
Hopkins baseball team has ever
undertaken so long a trip, and
the team very naturally is glad
that the change was made. In
the past the Hopkins team has
remained at home during the
Easter holidays to play various
northern colleges. When it was
learned, however, that Yale, Harvard and the other large colleges
were not coming south this year,
it was decided to •go north to
play them. As a result of this
decision, a game was booked with
Yale early this year, and then an
attempt was made to schedule a
game with Harvard at Cambridge.
Harvard, however, stated that
they could play Hopkins on Saturday, April 19, the date of the
already scheduled Yale-Hopkins
Unfortunately, neither
game.
Yale nor Harvard could change
the date; hence a game could not
be secured with Harvard.
It was at first planned to play
six games on the tour, but it was
thought that this would be a little too hard on the twirlers, and,
as a result, the number of the
games was cut down to four.
Holy Cross College, which had
one of the best college baseball
teams in the country last year,
wrote to the Hopkins manager

7

asking for a game on Monday,
April 21, and while no definite
decision has as yet been reached,
it is thought probable that the
game will be booked.
The record the team will make
on the trip of course cannot' be
foretold. Coach Eddie Hooper
and Captain Littman both feel,
however, that if the team has good
pitching it will make an enviable
record. Judefind and Love, two
right-handers, and Wallace, who
is a southpaw, will be taken on
the trip, and all ,of them are in
excellent form. Judefind's curve
ball is breaking better this year
than ever, and he has lost none
of his speed or cunning. Love is
also going ,along in wonderful
shape. With excellent control
this year he knows how to mix
up his wares to the discouragement of the opposing batters
Wallace is a find from the ,Medical school, and is perfectly capable of holding his own in fast
company.
Since all the colleges that will
be met on the trip have strong
teams, Hopkins will indeed have
made an excellent record if it can
come back with a string of victories. Yale and Columbia always have excellent teams.
Swarthmore, however, is not to
be overlooked. The Quakers had
a splendid nine last year, the
mainstay of which was the battery, which, incidentally, was the
best college battery in the country. While Ogden, their star
twirler, is not back at college this
year, having joined the New York
Nationals at the close of Swarthmore's season last year, their
catcher and practically all the
rest of the team are back in college. The Black and Blue tossers
defeated Haverford last season by
a comfortable margin.

Faculty News.

Sir Arthur Newsholme May Join Faculty.

"'Scientific Prepossession' and
Antiscientific Animus," is the title
of an article by Dr. Dunlap, published in the March 13 number
of "The Journal of Philosophy,
Psychology, and Scientific Methods." In this article Dr. Dunlap
attacks Professor Fite's carricature of scientific psychology
which appeared in the December
"Atlantic," and defends the scientific method as the only reliable
method of securing psychological
data.
Professors Wilfred P. Mustard
and C. W. E. Miller attended the
annual meeting of the Classical
Asociation of the Atlantic States,
held at Haverford College, Pa.,
April 4--5. Professor Mustard
read a paper on "Tasso's Debt to
Virgil," showing how Tasso used
the Aeneid as his epic model in
writing his "Jerusalem Delivered."

A London paper has it that Sir
Arthur Newsholme, the distinguished British hygienist, has
been invited to come to Baltimore
to become professor of public
health in the School of Public
Health and Hygiene of the Johns
Hopkins University. Neither the
trustees of the University nor the
faculty of the medical school
know anything about the invitation, and it is thought that a mistake has been made, though it is
considered possible by some that
Dr. Welch may have extended an
invitation. Dr. Welch is now in
Europe, so that this possibility
cannot be immediately verified.
Sir Arthur Newsholme is said
to be the most conspicuous of all
the men in the medical profession
in England in such work as the
Rockefeller School of Hygiene is
planning to do in this country,
and his acquisition by the Hopkins school would attract attention all over the world.

The, track team is all set for
the meet with Swarthmore this
Saturday at Homewood field, and
if the weather gives the men a•
dry field the events will be run
off in very fast time. With a
large squad of men to choose
from, Mr. England has picked a
team which from all advanced
dope ought to win by a safe
margin.
For the one hundred yard dash
Hopkins has a strong trio in B.
Smith, Van Ness and Crist. Although all of these men can do
the distance in around ten-one or
two, it is very probable that Crist
will lead the field at the finish.
To save Smith for later events
the 220 entries will be Van Ness,
Crist and either Hazeltine or
Driver. For ;the quarter mile
event two of the men from the
members of the championship
mile relay team will line up at
the start, and judging from the
easy fashion in which Hopkins
captured this event last year, first
and second places may be counted
upon.
The distant events will have
their entries somewhat changed
from the line-ups of former meets,
as Captain Smith, who, it seems,
can win in any distance from the
one hundred yard dash to a sixmile cross-country run, has shown
in trials his ability to beat the
Hopkins record in this distance
on a dry track. His running
mates will be either Bartels or L.
Cattanach. The mile run will
give Swarthmore no little concern
this year with Bartels, Norwood
and Mullikin entered, especially as
Bartels and Mullikin have, respectively, shared the honors of first
place in the S. A. I. A. A. mile
in the last two years. The two;
mile event will leave the odds to
Swarthmore, for although Rivkin
and Graves are good men they
will be a trifle young to go
against the veterans of the Pennsylvania team. M. Firor, last
year's captain, and R. Wood, the
freshman star, will be entered in
the hurdles; last year Firor took
first in both events without a
team mate, so that this year it
seems as though both places will
come our way.
For the field events Leadbetter
is a sure winner in the shot and
discus, while eaulkins will help
him out in the weight throwing,
and G. Cattanach can be counted
upon to run a close second with
the discus. Seagraves and tevenson will share the pole vault,
and although Swarthmore has
several strong men, a first or second ought to fall our way. Firor,
of course, can be counted upon
for the high jump, having again
as a mate R. Wood, and possibly
Norwood. The javelin throw is
new this year for most of the

Dr. John C. French Writes About
Tocqueville Medal.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—At the time appointed for
the preliminary trials for the 1919
Tocqueville contest, so few candidates appeared that the committee was unwilling to proceed with
the trial. Unless greater interest
is shown by the undergraduates
of this year, no 1919 medal will
be awarded. I am reluctant to believe that so important a prize is
regarded with indifference by so
many competent men. The Tocqueville medal has an international significance — not lessened by
the events of the past five years—
in that it is the gift of the Baron
Pierre de Coubertin, of Paris,
transmitted to the. University
through the French Government
and our own Department of State.
It is one of five such medals, differently named, given by the same
• donor to American colleges. Harvard, Princeton and Johns Hopkins are the threo colleges in the
East selected to receive these
prizes; Tulane is the one Southern college chosen; and Leland
Stanford and the University of
California compete jointly for the
fifth medal. The winning of the
Tocqueville medal, therefore, confers a distinction which any ambitious student may very properly
covet. Why so few have seemed
this year to covet it I cannot understand, unless the men who
should be interested in such matters have not been aware of its
importance.
That the lethargy of 1919 has
not existed in past years can best
be proved by a list of the men who
have already won the medal:
1900—James Edward Routh, Jr., A. B., Ph.
D. 1905, Lanier Professor of English
Literature, Oglethorpe University.
1903—Harry King Tootle, A. B., Journalist.
1904—Gerald Benjamin Rosenheim, A. B.,
Attorney at Law.
1905—John Francis Cremen, A. B., Insurance.
1906—Ormond Wilson Hammond, Jr. (Deceased).
1907—Oscar Ellis Bransky, A. B., Chemist.
1909—Samuel Claggett Chew, Jr., A. B.,
Associate Professor of English, Bryn
Mawr College.
1911—Earle Lindsay Rogers, A. B., Ph. D.
1915, Associate Professor of Political
Science, University of Virginia.
1912—Bertram Benedict, A. B., Social Work.
1913—John Sharpe Dickinson, A. B., U. S.
Army, attached to the General Staff.
1914—Aaron Schaffer, A. B., Ph, D. 1917,
Instructor, Johns Hopkins.
1915—No award.
•
1916—Reuben Oppenheimer, A. B., Harvard
Law School.
1917—Joseph L. Krieger, B. S. in Eng.,
Chemical Warfare Work.
1918—Wm. Samuel Hoffman, A. B., Chemical Warfare Work.

This list includes the names of
some of the ablest men who have
received the bachelor's degree at

Hopkins. Any student now in
residence might be proud to write
his name with theirs.
A second opportunity—and a
last one—to compete for places
in the final contest will be given
on Tuesday, April 29, at 1 o'clock
in Room 112. Dean Latane has
kindly consented to advise candidates as to the most convenient
sources of information about the
League of Nations. As was announced in the NEWS-LETTER of
last week, the subject of the discussions will be:
The Future of France as Influenced by a League of Nations.
Suggested sub-topics:
(a) The Future of France in
a Europe of Alliances and Balances of Power.
(b) The Burden of Reconstruction and National Defence.
(c) France and Sea-Power.
(d) What France Deserves
from Her Allies.
JOHN C. FRENCH.

RED EAGLES TAKE
CITY COLLEGE'S SCALP.

23 S. HANOVER ST.

The Hopkins lacrosse scrubs,
who glory under the name of the
Red Eagles defeated the City
College athletes last Wednesday
by the score of three to one. The
game was scrappy and only the
excellent defensive work of Barrett, who covered first defense,
prevented scoring on the part of
the visitors.
After eleven minutes of play,
Blum shot the first goal for Hopkins. A few minutes later Baker
added another tally to the score.
City was full of life and vigor,
but the speed and stick work of
the older men always warded off
the danger.
City tightened considerably in
the second half, and it was not
until the latter part of the game
that another tally was added by
Blum. Kirkpatrick, City's star
center, did his best to put the ball
in the net, but his efforts were in
vain.

Burger Irresistible Tickets on
Sale at the Post Office.

New laurels are about to be added to the many which have fallen.
to Hopkins' sons. On May 7 the
Johns Hopkins Dramatic Club
will present its first play, "You
Never Can Tell." Any doubtful
connection, however, between the
name and the outcome of the play
must be emphatically denied; anyone fortunate enough to have attended a rehearsal lately can bear
witness to the fact.
huge success.
In speaking with members of
the cast, the general impression
gathered is that the one big factor in their ultimate success will
have been the inestimable services of Miss Clementine Walter,
who is coaching the play. Not only
her ability in coaching is praised,
but also she has been overly generous in giving up her time and attention to the play. As indicative
of the unanimously high regard in
which Miss Walter's services are
regarded, the exclamation of one
of the players is significant:
"Now, I wonder where we'd be
without Miss Walter!"
The male parts are well played,
with Carneal, Leber, Morriss,
Heiner, Trew and Simon filling
the roles. The Waiter (Carneal)
allti Valentine (Leber) will certainly attract especial attention.
When it comes to the real stuff
though, the "ladies" are all there:
Lewin, Burger and Norris. Say,
fellows, you never saw such a
sweet, pretty, "bubbling over,"
dear, lovable, little angel as Dolly,
as played by Teddy Burger; she
has Lillian Gish and Mary Pickford all looking like old-timers!
And when John Lewin, as Mrs.
Clandon, swishes her "train" of
state, you might think you'd like
her for your mother-in-law—and
you might not! But we can't give
away the whole show.
Tickets for the performance are
now on sale at the postoffice, or by
any member of the Dramatic Club.
The tickets are $1, they must be
exchanged for seats at Albaugh's
ticket office, after April 21, where
they will be credited for that
amount toward the price of the
seat, the difference being paid
there if a more expensive seat is
desired. The prices are as follows: Box,.$2; orchestra (A to J),
$1.50; orchestra (remainder), $1;
mezanine, '$1; balcony, 75 cents.

YOUNG ENGINEERS GIVEN ADVICE

State Trims Hopkins Ball Team—Annapolis Stickmen Register

Aldred Lecturer Discloses What a Young

Ball Tossers Aided by Many Passes.
Dr. M. L. Raney, librarian of
the University, is again to sail to
Europe this week, as the official
representative of the American
Library Association. Dr. Raney
Spent four months in the spring
of 1918 in France and England
as the representative of the Association to establish library service for the American army and
navy overseas. His plans were
accepted by General Pershing and
Admiral Sims, who provided the
necessary tonnage for the transportation of this material to
Europe. The result is that the
Association has thus far shipped
overseas more than two and a half
million volumes. During the period of demobilization, it is the

The G. E. Aldred lecturer of
last week was Mr. H. S. Slocum,
whose theme was, "The Duties of
the Young Engineer in the Construction of a Hydro-Electric
Power Plant." The discourse was
accompanied throughout by the
projection of a fine set of slides
illustrating all the phases of the
work.
Mr. Slocum began his lecture
with an outline of the first steps
of the construction of a plant.
These included financial surveys,
designing of the plant, topographical surveys, and building of
roads, cableways and construction camps. The design of the
construction plant, including rock
.crushers, shops, storage places for
cement and coal, is an exceedingly interesting part of the labor.
Plotting of progress charts is
one of the duties that usually fall
to the young , engineer. These
show the cubic yards excavated,
number of men at work, concrete
completed, and other items of
progress and are of great value,
both in'
keeping the efficiency ,up
and in making a permanent record.
In the actual construction the
force is organized into parties,
each of which has the responsibility for one portion of the work.
In one case, for example, one
party made the excavation, built
the lining of the water-tunnel,
and put up the intake tower. A
second lined in the grades, and
inspected the construction. The
third had the construction of the
power house,—establishing the
center lines erecting the steelwork, installing the hydraulic machinery, and checking the lines of
the journals.
The construction of transmission lines is similar to railroad
work. One party clears the right
of way, another makes the excavations for the footings of the
towers, others put in the concrete,
assemble the towers, put them up,
set them on the footing, put on St
the insulators and string the
wires, respectively.
Inspection forms a large part
of the engineer's work. It must
be done with care and thoroughness, with as much attention to
details as to the more prominent
features.
The speaker closed with some
straightforward advice to young
men about to enter the practical
engineering field. They must

TO MAKE MANY INVESTIGATIONS
Williams Memorial Expedition To Take
Interesting Route Through Andes-Will
Return Next Fall After Thorough
Study of Mineral Deposits.

The George Huntington Williams Memorial Expedition will
sail from New York on April 18.
The party will consist of Professor Edward W. Berry, professor of palentology, Professor
Joseph T. Singewald, Jr., professor of economic .geology, and Mr.
Luis Velasco, a graduate student
of the department of geology and
a native of Bolivia. They will
proceed direct to Callao, Peru, via
the Panama Canal. After establishing relations with the geologists of the Peruvian Mining
Bureau, they will cross the western range of the Andes on the
Oroga railroad, which is the highest railroad in the world, climbing to an altitude of 15,865 feet
and continue to its terminus at
Huancayo. Here the party will
re-cross the range on mule-back
to the famous mercury mine at
Huancarelica, and after making
a geologic study of them they will
reach the coast of Pisco.
On the peninsula of Paracas,
near Pisco, the carboniferous
beds will be examined and collections of fossils made. From
Pisco the party will proceed to
Bollendo by steamer, and thence

by rail to Lake Titicaca, the highest body of navigable water in
the world. Though lying nestled
in the Andes at an elevation of
13,000 feet, so large is this intramountain lake that the trip
across requires a night's ride by
steamer. The principal goal of
the expedition will then have been
reached—the Andes of Bolivia.
The two chief objective points in
Bolivia and Corocoro and Potosi,
at both of these localities Professor Singewald made important
scientific discoveries during his
1915 expedition, and it is intended
to carry on further and more detailed work there by the William's
expedition. •
Corocoro is the largest copper
district in Bolivia and shares the
unique distinction with the Lake
Superior district of the United
States of having much of the ore
occur in the form of the native
metal. Potosi was the richest and
most productive of the old Spanish silver districts in South America. The mines have been
worked continuously since their
discovery in 1534, and even today
are important producers of tin
and silver.
The eastern range of the Andes
will be crossed at several places
in order to study the geologic
history of that range and its mineralization.
On completing their work in
Bolivia, the party will again

"The Educational Opportunity"
was the subject on which U. S.
Commissioner of Education Philander P. Claxton talked at the
Life Work Lecture last Tuesday.
Mr. Claxton gave these three
questions for consideration before
deciding on a life work: (1)
What can be accomplished for
others by doing the work? (2)
How much pleasure and enjoyment can be got for oneself?
(3) Can a decent living be made
in the work?
In answer to the question of
what can be done for others, Mr.
Claxton emphasized the tremendous need of education brought on
by the war. The war has democratized the world and illiterate
people cannot function in a democracy. The whole world must
be educated so that the democracies may succeed in giving their
people prosperity. The war has
greatly cut down the man power
of the world. To replace this,
labor-saving machines must be
used and this involves teaching
laborers to run the machines.
The pleasures of the school
teacher are very great. The
teacher feels that he is doing
something worth while for society; he sees his former scholars go out into life and gets great
•satisfaction when he hears of
splendid achievements of some of
them; and, greater still, he has
the joy of living with younger
people and watching them develop.
Although the income of the
school teacher is at present
small, Mr. Claxton believes that
we are at the beginning of a period of increasing incomes for
teachers and predicts that soon
instructors will be paid a salary
which will bear a close correlation to the great benefits they
bestow on mankind.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 15, 1919
The Pride of the Navy.

We are neither poor sports nor
hard losers. We have gracefully
suffered defeats enough to refute
that charge, for "Palnutm qui
meruit ferat" has always been the
Hopkins motto, especially in regard to athletic contests. The
Navy lacrosse game—if it can be
called a game—should not, however, fall under the category of
those which Hopkins has lost because of the clean, superior play
of her opponents. The Academy
has sustained a disgrace which
cannot easily be wiped out.
The first half of the game,
though bitterly contested, was free
from the terrific slugging that
characterized the last few minutes
of play. Though the Navy brand
of lacrosse did not have the sportsmanlike character of that of Lehigh and other Hopkins opponents, still we should have registered no kick had the remainder
of the game been so played. At
the end of the half, the score stood
two all. After much seesawing
of the ball, Hopkins finally netted
another goal. Then a peculiar psychological factor entered in. We
shall pay the big Navy team the
delicate compliment that they are
distinctly unlike the Huns, who,
former prisoners in their camps
tell us, were astoundingly arrogant and brutal when winning,
but cajolingly gentle when they
saw they had lost. Navy, seeing

•

that the enemy was in the lead
and that there were only seven
more minutei to play, was, in the
literal sense, out for blood.
"Eggie" Sutton was knocked
out with a deep cut on the head,
and time was called till it could
be bandaged. When he .returned
to the game, his bandaged head
was noticeably a target for the
Annapolis stickmen. After sustaining repeated blows on this injured member, he finally fell under a particularly vicious swing,
and, with blood flowing freely, was
carried from the field.
Four other Black and Blue
stickwielders — Defandorf, Beall,
Baxley and Silberstein, far from
the largest men on the team, the
latter with wide open cuts on the
head — were in quick succession
laid out on the field. Hoffman,
also, received a nasty gash on the
cheek. Time was repeatedy called,
these men pluckily coming back
for more, and several of the Navy
team were ejected for a few minutes. But why go into the details? It was pronounced by experts the finest exhibition of dirty
playing they had ever seen.
Navy had an overwhelming
share of weight and brawn, which
they figured they could use to advantage. Had it come to a mutual slugging match, they would
have had the edge. As it was onesided slugging, not a Navy man
was knocked out or badly cut
while many of the Black and Blue
will show for many a day that
they were in a dirty game. Many
of the cuts were received by the
Hopkins stickers after they had
gotten the ball away.
The score has no bearing on the
issue; we offer no alibis. Had it
been an overwhelming victory for
the 'Varsity, we would voice the
same complaint against dirty
playing. The Schmeissers and
Reaney Wolfe must have felt
deeply the perversion into such
channels of the game they have
done so much to foster; and, indeed, they had no hesitancy in expressing themselves.
Several midshipmen, after the
game admitted that from the
standpoint of lacrosse, Navy was
outplayed; and another advanced
the unique theory that those Navy
men that had a grudge against the
world in general went out for lacrosse as a means of venting their
spleen. At all events, whatever
the molly& of the Annapolis
twelve, Saturday's exhibition is a
blot upon the athletic fame of the
Naval Academy; and should a
repetition of the affair ever occur
where Hopkins is concerned, athletic relations between the two institutions should promptly be
severed.
As for the 'Varsity, they played
the game of their lives and stood
up with the old Hopkins spirit
under the unnecessary punishment. Boys, we're all mighty
damned proud of you!

cannot afford to fall down on the

MUSICAL CONCERT APRIL 26th.
Haverford Musical Clubs and Hopkins
Glee Club Will Stage Concert and
Dance in C. E.Building—To Take
Place of McCoy Hall Concert.

The Musical Clubs of Ha verford
College and the Glee Club of
Johns Hopkins will give a joint
concert at Homewood on Saturday evening, April 26. Following
the concert there will be a formal
dance. This concert is to take
the place of the McCoy Hall concert, which is staged annually by
the Johns Hopkins Musical Clubs.
It will be one of the leading social
functions of the University this
season as the McCoy Hall concert
has been in years past.
The Haverford Musical Clubs
have had a remarkable season, and
are at their best just at this time.
They consist of a mandolin and
it glee club, and they feature several other intereStina numbers.
The athletic teams of Hopkins and
Haverford have held contests for a
number of years and this concert
by the combine'
d musical clubs is
just another tie which will draw
the two colleges closer together.
The Johns Hopkins Glee Club
has been under the direction of
Prof. Charles H. Bo(thau for the
last two months, and is in fine
shape for the concert on the 26th
of April. There are about thirty
men on the club at this time.
Tickets to the concert and
dance may be secured from any
members of the (nee Club. The
place is the Civil Engineering
Hall, Homewood, and the time is
8 P. M., April 26.

Tennis Match Dates Announced.

The tennis team has just one
more week in which to fit itself
for the opening game with Navy,
at Annapolis, on April 19.
For the-past three weeks Captain Keyes has been kept busy
trying to pick out the men he shall
semi to play Navy. He finally announced that the team will probably consist of Symington, Duffy,
Keyes, Ward and Kesting.
The practice for the remainder
of this week will be mainly devoted to doubles, for which, up to
the present time, no teams have
been selected.
After this week's practice, the
team should be in first rate condition to carry out the schedule
which Manager Hoffmeister has
announced. It is as follows:
April 19—Navy, at Navy.
April 26—George Washington,
at home.
May 3—Western Maryland, at
Western Maryland.
May 9—Princeton, at home.
May 10—Columbia, at home.
May 16—Swarthmore, at home.
M ay 17—Ha verford, at home.
May 23—University of Pennsylvania, at home.
May 24—Delaware College, at
Newark.

IMPORTANCE OF THE LIBRARY
(By Ernest Cushing Richardson, Ph. D., Librarian of Princeton University.)
Somebody has put up to the
University Librarian the question:
how shall a freshman go to work
to get the best use out of the library during his course. The idea
was that a man enters college
with a vague idea that the library
is for use and that it might be
used to better fit him for life
work, or even to help him to enjoy his college life itself, if he
only knew how to go to work at it.
The possible uses of the library
are as various as the men and
their special interest. The uses
made by research professors and
graduate students for the discovery of new knowledge is one
thing; the use by professors for
students in aid of class room
work is another, and the free use
of the library by a student for
his voluntary activities and private tastes is another, or rather
two more.
Use for assigned reading may
be left out of account. The professors will tell about this, inch
by inch. It is to the matter of
free use by a man on his own
initiative that this question
points, and, useful as a library is
for organized teaching and learning, and fundamental as it is for
graduate or undergraduate directed research, its best use for
the undergraduate, is its voluntary use.
* * *
The habit of merely looking
over the literature or even the
titles of the books and periodical
articles bearing on the questions
involved, is one of the very best
possible ways of stimulating
thought and suggesting points of
view. Especially in these modern
days when every one is after some
new thing and modern points of
view, it is in the periodical articles that he must find it. Merely
to look over the periodical indexes, therefore, under any topic
suggest twenty variations,
may
,
aspects or points of view, and the
habit of so doing is invaluable.
It follows, too, that the very frequent running in to glance over
the periodicals which handle the
topics involved is the greatest
possible contribution to a fresh
intellectual interest in these topics, and this is after all the main
thing all along the line. Whatever will kindle the intellectual
interest helps towards good use—
interest kindled, usefulness follows almost without effort.
*

*

*

lege curriculum and would add to
it a capacity for understanding
and 'taking interest immeasurable
in terms of arithmetic.
No doubt, however, the best use
that a freshman can plan to make
of a library his whole course long
is not to browse over good books
but to seek out all the best books
and read at least a few of the
very best. By this is meant to
look over with a certain amount
of care some of the very best elementary looks on all matters of
science or history, literature, or
religion, which do not come
within the field of his courses,
doing this as a part of his fifteen
minutes a day, or putting in all
his spare time on it—if he finds
matters of special interest—when
he has the spare time. It means
still more, however, the frequent
handling of the books which are
recognized as the very best, that
is to say, the classics of literature, ancient and modern. Of
course, the average freshman has
no use to begin with for these
classics. The use even of the
English classics is an acquired
taste. The taste is one, however,
which grows very fast with widening interest in all aspects of
human life and thought. The reason of the value of the classics
is that they are concentrated
food, all such books are a survival of the fittest ttnd they are
the fittest because they concentrate in themselves the largest
amount of human experience.
What they are is what human
experience from the beginning of
the world has found true. Their
value is proved by the fact of
their survival. For this very reason, however, they are strong
meat for beginners. Many never
grow up to really enjoy even their
Shakespeare, and it may , be
doubted whether they can hope
to without some wide practice in
the more diluted literature of humanity—Tennyson, Kipling, Dickens, Thackeray, Trollope, Archibald Marshall.
The most important way of using the library is, after all, simply
using it. The mere habit of use
develops ways of use. A man
cannot systematically make a
point of being among books without finding ways in which their
use profits him. The more he
handles the tools of using such
as the author and subject catalogues, the indexes to periodicals,
and the reference books in general,
so that he is able at any time,
with the least expenditure of effort, to get what he wants over
the counter or from the books on
open shelves, the greater the value
and interest of use becomes. It
is curious to one who deals with
such things to note how skill
multiplies interest as well as results.—The Daily Princetonian.

SOCIAL SCIENCE CLUB MEETS;
OFFICERS ARE ELECTED.

Embryo Engineers Witness Launching
of Steel Ship.

At the first meeting of the Social Science Club, held last week,
Frank Morley, Jr, was elected
president; M. Guttmacher, secretary - treasurer, and Professor
Lovejoy, club counsellor. The aims
of the club are to help college men
get ready intellectually to face the
problems of social readjustments
which will arise in the years to
come, and to give them a view of
the many sides of the social problem. A well informed speaker will
present some questions at a public
meeting of the club, and the next
week an open discussion by the
members of the club will be held.
The club will not be run like a
debating society, which Dr. Lovejoy characterized as an evidence
of the survival in college of juvenile tendencies and a mild form
of college athletics.
Dr. Lovejoy, in addressing the
club, said that even if the college men of today wished to dodge
the questions of the social problem, they could not; because the
questions will be forced upon them
for solution in the next thirty or
forty years.
The topics for discussion for
the remainder of the year are to
be: (1) The indictment of the
Present Social Order; (2) Trade
Unionism; and (3) Bolshevism:
What Is It and What Is Its
Actual Program With Respect to,
(a) Political Organization, (b)
Organization and Management of
Industry, (c) Economic Distribution?
The principal texts to be used
for reference will be: "Political
Ideals," by B. Russell, an extreme
radical; Prof. J. Hollander's "The
Abolition of Poverty," a book that
holds the middle way between the
extremes of radicalism and conservatism; and "Essays in Social
Justice," by Prof. T. N. Carver,
an apologist of individualism.
Meetings of the club are to be
held weekly on Thursday nights,
at 8 P. M., at the Barn. The
charge for active membership for
the remainder of the year will be
50 cents. Active members will
have the privilege of voting and
will at times be assigned active
parts in the discussion. All University students are welcome at
any meeting and assume no obligation to pay dues by corning and
joining in the discussion.
An executive committee was appointed to consider and arrange
to secure speakers, to send out
notices and the like. This committee is composed of the officers
of the club — W. Bloom, H. E.
Niles, C. T. Leber and P. Hayes.

The members of the upper
classes of the Engineering Department were afforded last Saturday
noon an opportunity of witnessing
the launching of one of the 8,800ton steel ships now being built at
the Baltimore Dry Docks and
Shipbuilding Company.
.The party from Hopkins, under
the command of Mr. Pullen, was
able to get "box seats" along the
edge of a pier so close that everything could be seen but the champagne ceremony and the band.
Promptly at 12 the beam was
sawed and the skids began to slip
down the greased ways. Those
who had attended the Aldred lecture on shipbuilding began to look
for the smoke that would indicate
that the high friction was burning the wood; the others watched
the big wave pushed up by the
stern of the ship. After the ship
left the ways, waiting tugs came
up, took the cables that were
thrown to them, and guided the
ship around into the channel.
Before the launching, the budding engineers were taken around
the plant. The large drydock with
a Norwegian ship on the blocks,
was the first object of interest.
The men were replacing a number
of bent plates, the accident being
caused (according to several wild.
conjectures) by a torpedo, or maybe a typhoon. After this, they were
shown the mold-loft, where the
wooden templates were being
made. The next stop was at the
shop where the plates and ribs
were cut, shaped and punched.
These trips are made by the engineers nearly every week, giving
the students a chance to observe
time practical as well as the theoretical part of their future profession.

The Johns Hopkins baseball
team will leave Baltimore this
Thursday morning for their northern trip, which will include four
games in different northern cities. On Thursday afternoon the
Black and Blue ball tossers will
stack up against the strong
Columbia University nine in New
York. Friday will be a day of
rest for the team, and on Saturday morning they will journey to
New Haven to tackle the Yale
nine.'
The team will return to New
York Sunday morning and will
remain there Sunday and Monday. They will leave the big city
Thesday morning for Swartlunore,
remaining there the night after
the game with Swarthmore.
Wednesday morning the nine will
leave for Haverford, Pa., to play
the Haverford team that afternoon.
This is the first time that the
Hopkins baseball team has ever
undertaken so long a trip, and
the team very naturally is glad
that the change was made. In
the past the Hopkins team has
remained at home during the
Easter holidays to play various
northern colleges. When it was
learned, however, that Yale, Harvard and the other large colleges
were not coming south this year,
it was decided to •go north to
play them. As a result of this
decision, a game was booked with
Yale early this year, and then an
attempt was made to schedule a
game with Harvard at Cambridge.
Harvard, however, stated that
they could play Hopkins on Saturday, April 19, the date of the
already scheduled Yale-Hopkins
Unfortunately, neither
game.
Yale nor Harvard could change
the date; hence a game could not
be secured with Harvard.
It was at first planned to play
six games on the tour, but it was
thought that this would be a little too hard on the twirlers, and,
as a result, the number of the
games was cut down to four.
Holy Cross College, which had
one of the best college baseball
teams in the country last year,
wrote to the Hopkins manager

7

asking for a game on Monday,
April 21, and while no definite
decision has as yet been reached,
it is thought probable that the
game will be booked.
The record the team will make
on the trip of course cannot' be
foretold. Coach Eddie Hooper
and Captain Littman both feel,
however, that if the team has good
pitching it will make an enviable
record. Judefind and Love, two
right-handers, and Wallace, who
is a southpaw, will be taken on
the trip, and all ,of them are in
excellent form. Judefind's curve
ball is breaking better this year
than ever, and he has lost none
of his speed or cunning. Love is
also going ,along in wonderful
shape. With excellent control
this year he knows how to mix
up his wares to the discouragement of the opposing batters
Wallace is a find from the ,Medical school, and is perfectly capable of holding his own in fast
company.
Since all the colleges that will
be met on the trip have strong
teams, Hopkins will indeed have
made an excellent record if it can
come back with a string of victories. Yale and Columbia always have excellent teams.
Swarthmore, however, is not to
be overlooked. The Quakers had
a splendid nine last year, the
mainstay of which was the battery, which, incidentally, was the
best college battery in the country. While Ogden, their star
twirler, is not back at college this
year, having joined the New York
Nationals at the close of Swarthmore's season last year, their
catcher and practically all the
rest of the team are back in college. The Black and Blue tossers
defeated Haverford last season by
a comfortable margin.

Faculty News.

Sir Arthur Newsholme May Join Faculty.

"'Scientific Prepossession' and
Antiscientific Animus," is the title
of an article by Dr. Dunlap, published in the March 13 number
of "The Journal of Philosophy,
Psychology, and Scientific Methods." In this article Dr. Dunlap
attacks Professor Fite's carricature of scientific psychology
which appeared in the December
"Atlantic," and defends the scientific method as the only reliable
method of securing psychological
data.
Professors Wilfred P. Mustard
and C. W. E. Miller attended the
annual meeting of the Classical
Asociation of the Atlantic States,
held at Haverford College, Pa.,
April 4--5. Professor Mustard
read a paper on "Tasso's Debt to
Virgil," showing how Tasso used
the Aeneid as his epic model in
writing his "Jerusalem Delivered."

A London paper has it that Sir
Arthur Newsholme, the distinguished British hygienist, has
been invited to come to Baltimore
to become professor of public
health in the School of Public
Health and Hygiene of the Johns
Hopkins University. Neither the
trustees of the University nor the
faculty of the medical school
know anything about the invitation, and it is thought that a mistake has been made, though it is
considered possible by some that
Dr. Welch may have extended an
invitation. Dr. Welch is now in
Europe, so that this possibility
cannot be immediately verified.
Sir Arthur Newsholme is said
to be the most conspicuous of all
the men in the medical profession
in England in such work as the
Rockefeller School of Hygiene is
planning to do in this country,
and his acquisition by the Hopkins school would attract attention all over the world.

The, track team is all set for
the meet with Swarthmore this
Saturday at Homewood field, and
if the weather gives the men a•
dry field the events will be run
off in very fast time. With a
large squad of men to choose
from, Mr. England has picked a
team which from all advanced
dope ought to win by a safe
margin.
For the one hundred yard dash
Hopkins has a strong trio in B.
Smith, Van Ness and Crist. Although all of these men can do
the distance in around ten-one or
two, it is very probable that Crist
will lead the field at the finish.
To save Smith for later events
the 220 entries will be Van Ness,
Crist and either Hazeltine or
Driver. For ;the quarter mile
event two of the men from the
members of the championship
mile relay team will line up at
the start, and judging from the
easy fashion in which Hopkins
captured this event last year, first
and second places may be counted
upon.
The distant events will have
their entries somewhat changed
from the line-ups of former meets,
as Captain Smith, who, it seems,
can win in any distance from the
one hundred yard dash to a sixmile cross-country run, has shown
in trials his ability to beat the
Hopkins record in this distance
on a dry track. His running
mates will be either Bartels or L.
Cattanach. The mile run will
give Swarthmore no little concern
this year with Bartels, Norwood
and Mullikin entered, especially as
Bartels and Mullikin have, respectively, shared the honors of first
place in the S. A. I. A. A. mile
in the last two years. The two;
mile event will leave the odds to
Swarthmore, for although Rivkin
and Graves are good men they
will be a trifle young to go
against the veterans of the Pennsylvania team. M. Firor, last
year's captain, and R. Wood, the
freshman star, will be entered in
the hurdles; last year Firor took
first in both events without a
team mate, so that this year it
seems as though both places will
come our way.
For the field events Leadbetter
is a sure winner in the shot and
discus, while eaulkins will help
him out in the weight throwing,
and G. Cattanach can be counted
upon to run a close second with
the discus. Seagraves and tevenson will share the pole vault,
and although Swarthmore has
several strong men, a first or second ought to fall our way. Firor,
of course, can be counted upon
for the high jump, having again
as a mate R. Wood, and possibly
Norwood. The javelin throw is
new this year for most of the

Dr. John C. French Writes About
Tocqueville Medal.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—At the time appointed for
the preliminary trials for the 1919
Tocqueville contest, so few candidates appeared that the committee was unwilling to proceed with
the trial. Unless greater interest
is shown by the undergraduates
of this year, no 1919 medal will
be awarded. I am reluctant to believe that so important a prize is
regarded with indifference by so
many competent men. The Tocqueville medal has an international significance — not lessened by
the events of the past five years—
in that it is the gift of the Baron
Pierre de Coubertin, of Paris,
transmitted to the. University
through the French Government
and our own Department of State.
It is one of five such medals, differently named, given by the same
• donor to American colleges. Harvard, Princeton and Johns Hopkins are the threo colleges in the
East selected to receive these
prizes; Tulane is the one Southern college chosen; and Leland
Stanford and the University of
California compete jointly for the
fifth medal. The winning of the
Tocqueville medal, therefore, confers a distinction which any ambitious student may very properly
covet. Why so few have seemed
this year to covet it I cannot understand, unless the men who
should be interested in such matters have not been aware of its
importance.
That the lethargy of 1919 has
not existed in past years can best
be proved by a list of the men who
have already won the medal:
1900—James Edward Routh, Jr., A. B., Ph.
D. 1905, Lanier Professor of English
Literature, Oglethorpe University.
1903—Harry King Tootle, A. B., Journalist.
1904—Gerald Benjamin Rosenheim, A. B.,
Attorney at Law.
1905—John Francis Cremen, A. B., Insurance.
1906—Ormond Wilson Hammond, Jr. (Deceased).
1907—Oscar Ellis Bransky, A. B., Chemist.
1909—Samuel Claggett Chew, Jr., A. B.,
Associate Professor of English, Bryn
Mawr College.
1911—Earle Lindsay Rogers, A. B., Ph. D.
1915, Associate Professor of Political
Science, University of Virginia.
1912—Bertram Benedict, A. B., Social Work.
1913—John Sharpe Dickinson, A. B., U. S.
Army, attached to the General Staff.
1914—Aaron Schaffer, A. B., Ph, D. 1917,
Instructor, Johns Hopkins.
1915—No award.
•
1916—Reuben Oppenheimer, A. B., Harvard
Law School.
1917—Joseph L. Krieger, B. S. in Eng.,
Chemical Warfare Work.
1918—Wm. Samuel Hoffman, A. B., Chemical Warfare Work.

This list includes the names of
some of the ablest men who have
received the bachelor's degree at

Hopkins. Any student now in
residence might be proud to write
his name with theirs.
A second opportunity—and a
last one—to compete for places
in the final contest will be given
on Tuesday, April 29, at 1 o'clock
in Room 112. Dean Latane has
kindly consented to advise candidates as to the most convenient
sources of information about the
League of Nations. As was announced in the NEWS-LETTER of
last week, the subject of the discussions will be:
The Future of France as Influenced by a League of Nations.
Suggested sub-topics:
(a) The Future of France in
a Europe of Alliances and Balances of Power.
(b) The Burden of Reconstruction and National Defence.
(c) France and Sea-Power.
(d) What France Deserves
from Her Allies.
JOHN C. FRENCH.

RED EAGLES TAKE
CITY COLLEGE'S SCALP.

23 S. HANOVER ST.

The Hopkins lacrosse scrubs,
who glory under the name of the
Red Eagles defeated the City
College athletes last Wednesday
by the score of three to one. The
game was scrappy and only the
excellent defensive work of Barrett, who covered first defense,
prevented scoring on the part of
the visitors.
After eleven minutes of play,
Blum shot the first goal for Hopkins. A few minutes later Baker
added another tally to the score.
City was full of life and vigor,
but the speed and stick work of
the older men always warded off
the danger.
City tightened considerably in
the second half, and it was not
until the latter part of the game
that another tally was added by
Blum. Kirkpatrick, City's star
center, did his best to put the ball
in the net, but his efforts were in
vain.

Female Roles in Dramatic Club Production Excellently Portrayed—"Teddy"
Burger Irresistible Tickets on
Sale at the Post Office.

New laurels are about to be added to the many which have fallen.
to Hopkins' sons. On May 7 the
Johns Hopkins Dramatic Club
will present its first play, "You
Never Can Tell." Any doubtful
connection, however, between the
name and the outcome of the play
must be emphatically denied; anyone fortunate enough to have attended a rehearsal lately can bear
witness to the fact.
huge success.
In speaking with members of
the cast, the general impression
gathered is that the one big factor in their ultimate success will
have been the inestimable services of Miss Clementine Walter,
who is coaching the play. Not only
her ability in coaching is praised,
but also she has been overly generous in giving up her time and attention to the play. As indicative
of the unanimously high regard in
which Miss Walter's services are
regarded, the exclamation of one
of the players is significant:
"Now, I wonder where we'd be
without Miss Walter!"
The male parts are well played,
with Carneal, Leber, Morriss,
Heiner, Trew and Simon filling
the roles. The Waiter (Carneal)
allti Valentine (Leber) will certainly attract especial attention.
When it comes to the real stuff
though, the "ladies" are all there:
Lewin, Burger and Norris. Say,
fellows, you never saw such a
sweet, pretty, "bubbling over,"
dear, lovable, little angel as Dolly,
as played by Teddy Burger; she
has Lillian Gish and Mary Pickford all looking like old-timers!
And when John Lewin, as Mrs.
Clandon, swishes her "train" of
state, you might think you'd like
her for your mother-in-law—and
you might not! But we can't give
away the whole show.
Tickets for the performance are
now on sale at the postoffice, or by
any member of the Dramatic Club.
The tickets are $1, they must be
exchanged for seats at Albaugh's
ticket office, after April 21, where
they will be credited for that
amount toward the price of the
seat, the difference being paid
there if a more expensive seat is
desired. The prices are as follows: Box,.$2; orchestra (A to J),
$1.50; orchestra (remainder), $1;
mezanine, '$1; balcony, 75 cents.
